Question_1.Context: Proteases can be classified based on the peptide bond hydrolyzed and the optimal pH for their action.
Question_1.Question: Which type of proteases cleave the N- or C-terminal peptide bond?
Question_1.Source: Depending on the peptide bond hydrolyzed, proteases can be divided into exopeptidases, which cleave the N- or C-terminal peptide bond...

Question_2.Context: Microorganisms have the ability to secrete various types of proteases.
Question_2.Question: Which microorganism is known to secrete alkaline proteases?
Question_2.Source: For example, the bacterium Bacillus cereus is known to secrete alkaline proteases...

Question_3.Context: Salt-tolerant proteases (STPs) are known for their high salt tolerance and wider adaptability.
Question_3.Question: What is the approximate concentration of NaCl that salt-tolerant proteases can withstand?
Question_3.Source: STPs are known for their high salt tolerance, and are able to withstand concentrations of approximately 3.0 M NaCl or higher...

Question_4.Context: STPs can be used in various industries due to their unique properties.
Question_4.Question: In which industry can STPs help improve water quality by breaking down complex organic compounds?
Question_4.Source: In the environmental industry, STPs can help improve water quality by breaking down complex organic compounds in industrial wastewater into simpler, more easily removable forms...

Question_5.Context: Different microorganisms produce STPs with varying properties.
Question_5.Question: Which microorganism produces an alkaline protease that can remain stable in NaCl up to 20% (w/v)?
Question_5.Source: The alkaline protease from the halotolerant alkaliphilic Bacillus sp. strain NPST-AK15 can remain stable in NaCl up to 20% (w/v)...

Question_6.Context: STPs have shown promising applications in various food products.
Question_6.Question: Which protease has potential applications in soy sauce production?
Question_6.A: Alkaline protease from Bacillus sp. strain NPST-AK15
Question_6.B: Salt-tolerant neutral protease from Aspergillus oryzae
Question_6.D: Alkaline proteases used in detergent formulations
Question_6.Source: The salt-tolerant neutral protease from Aspergillus oryzae CICIM F0899 has shown high salt tolerance in 18% NaCl and can maintain 72% of its initial activity after 14 days...

Question_7.Context: STPs have been reported to have different enzymatic properties.
Question_7.Question: Which protease can maintain 60% activity in 3.5 M NaCl concentration?
Question_7.A: Alkaline protease from Bacillus sp. strain NPST-AK15
Question_7.B: Salt-tolerant neutral protease from Aspergillus oryzae
Question_7.D: Alkaline proteases used in detergent formulations
Question_7.Source: The acid protease from Rhodotorula mucilaginosa L7 can maintain 60% activity in 3.5 M NaCl concentration...

Question_8.Context: Microorganisms producing STPs have been isolated from various high-salt environments.
Question_8.Question: Where have the strains producing STPs been isolated from?
Question_8.Source: Notably, the strains have been isolated from various high-salt environments such as saline soils, seawater, lakes, and marine sediments...

Question_9.Context: STPs from microorganisms differ in their properties and potential applications.
Question_9.Question: Which type of proteases are most commonly reported among STPs from microorganisms?
Question_9.Source: Most of the reported STPs from microorganisms are alkaline proteases, while reports of salt-tolerant neutral proteases and acid proteases are few...

Question_10.Context: Research has focused on uncovering novel STPs with superior properties.
Question_10.Question: What techniques have been used to uncover novel STPs with superior properties?
Question_10.Source: These studies have focused on screening or identifying novel salt-tolerant microorganisms from different ecological environments using various modern techniques to uncover novel STPs with superior properties...
